message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question describes postpartum hemorrhage, and the treatment was not successful, resulting in the need for a hysterectomy. Ligating the vessels running through the cardinal ligament is necessary during the surgery to achieve hemostasis. The suspensory ligament, round ligament, and ovarian ligament do not play a significant role in achieving hemostasis during a hysterectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The structures that are ligated to achieve hemostasis during a hysterectomy are the uterine arteries, which run through the cardinal ligament. The other options do not contain the vessels that need to be ligated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The structures running through the cardinal ligament must be ligated to achieve hemostasis during the surgery. These structures include the uterine artery, the vaginal artery, and the ureter. The other ligaments listed (suspensory, round, ovarian) are not typically involved in achieving hemostasis during a hysterectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The uterine vessels run through the cardinal ligament, which must be ligated during a hysterectomy for hemostasis. The suspensory ligament contains the ovarian vessels, the round ligament connects the uterus to the labia majora, and the ovarian ligament attaches the ovary to the uterus, none of which are involved in achieving hemostasis in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bleeding is likely due to uterine atony, which requires a hysterectomy for treatment. To achieve hemostasis, vessels running through the cardinal ligament must be ligated as it contains the uterine vessels. The other options do not contain major vessels that require ligation for hemostasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vessels that need to be ligated to achieve hemostasis run through the cardinal ligament. The suspensory ligament contains the ovarian vessels, the round ligament contains the uterine vessels, and the ovarian ligament connects the ovary to the uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the vaginal bleeding and soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus suggest postpartum hemorrhage. The cardinal ligament contains the uterine vessels and must be ligated to achieve hemostasis during a hysterectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The appropriate structure to ligate during the surgery to achieve hemostasis is the cardinal ligament, which provides support for the cervix and upper vagina and contains the uterine artery, as well as other important structures such as the ureter and autonomic nerves. Ligation of the other options (suspensory ligament, round ligament, ovarian ligament) would not achieve hemostasis in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the uterus as soft, enlarged, and boggy suggests uterine atony as the cause of the bleeding. In order to achieve hemostasis during a hysterectomy, vessels running through the cardinal ligament must be ligated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The structures mentioned are all important ligaments in female reproductive anatomy, but ligating the vessels running through the cardinal ligament is necessary during hysterectomy for hemostasis. The cardinal ligament contains the uterine artery and vein, which supply blood to the uterus. Ligation of these vessels is necessary to prevent further bleeding.
